pages.text: Miniature Schnauzers have two genes that affect how they look, the B Locus and the D Locus. The B Locus determines whether the dog has red fur or black fur with tan points. The D Locus is a dilution that lightens black fur to a chocolate brown.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates red fur, while the 'b' allele creates black fur and creates a primarily black coat with tan points. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the black trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for black pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either black carriers or black puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The D Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'D' and the recessive 'd'. The 'D' allele does not affect the coat's color, while the 'd' allele is a dilute that lightens black fur to a chocolate brown. This gene is only visible on black and tan dogs, creating chocolate and tan dogs. Dogs with one copy of 'd' will carry the dilution trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for diluted pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'd' will always create either dilute carriers or diluted puppies.
pages.title: D Locus
